text: Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Uh some data that said people who are on Enzalutamide stay on Enzalutamide and get these drugs uh may have a higher response rate, and that’s what we are testing. Patient: Okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We have done this already in fifteen men and I think three people benefited for a period of time, relatively short. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But still benefited and so they did not have Enzalutamide or the Xtandi, so we’re doing fifteen more who have Xtandi uh and seeing whether or not it’s a higher response because of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So technically your ARV7 right now is positive enough to go on, your PSA is rising, you’re on the Xtandi, okay. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: The worry is the lungs, okay because this is a treatment that if we turn on your immune system so loud it can attack your normal body. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: So you can get a non-infectious pneumonia and get really short of breath and it fills up with scar tissue and s tuff like that and that we have to stop with steroids.

text: Family Member: So you wouldn’t suggest that he does a lot of walking. Doctor: At this moment, I wouldn’t; I’d just chill out. Time to just kick back. You’ve moved in; don’t do anything else. Patient: We’ve got a lot of Christmas shopping to do. Family Member: I can do the Christmas shopping. Doctor: Why don’t you get on the scooter thing? Family Member: No, he ain’t gonna do that. Doctor: Oh my gosh! Family Member: But you know he’s bad about taking his pain pills, too. Family Member: Will this actually take care of the pain, help with the pain – what he’s getting? Doctor: Yes, that’s actually. The indication is two things. One, it actually makes you live longer. That’s a good thing, like Xtandi, you take it because it’s gonna help you live longer. The other thing is it helps with pain and it reduces the pain. Family Member: Can he take Xtandi with it? Will that help him or is he going to continually take it? Doctor: So those studies are ongoing, and we normally would get – you know we normally do it like in sequence, like well you did that and now that drug doesn’t work, so now we’re on this. And then you did that, and now that drug doesn’t work and you’re on this. So I normally will take you off. So what my suggestion is we take you off of this for now. We get you in to see the radiation doctor, and when he starts you, because it’s a he, it’s Dr. __, he will see you, make sure you know we go through the insurance checks and all this other jazz. Then when he starts, we can figure out whether you want to start folding back in the Xtandi. But for now, I think we’ll just do one at a time because you’re also sensitive to some things. And then you know we get it in you and you’re on that Xtandi it might be too toxic. Family Member: You might not know what’s making you feel –

text: Patient: So, um, you know, I’m concerned for my son. My brother. Uh. He might have something too. I mean, if I try somethin’, it will help ‘em. Doctor: Yeah. I mean, so this may not help you, but it may help us learn how to treat other men in the future. Uh. So, that is, you know, just you being a good citizen and helping that out and a hero, but that – you have to feel comfortable with that, you know, ‘cuz it could help. It may not help. If it does help, it may help others. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um. And yet it’s your time. It’s your coming in here. Some of it’s your expense. You know, this drug enzalutamide, I don’t know what you were paying when you were on it before. Uh. It’s pretty expensive. It’s about ten thousand bucks a month. Um. And again, you would be taking it, even though we don’t think it’s gonna work ‘cuz -- because we think that it may make the immune therapy work better. So, we have to have people on it. Their PSA’s gonna be rising. Their ARV seven still has to be positive. (Laughs) Patient: Okay. I didn’t pay much for the Xtandi before. Uh, some kind of study from manufacturers – Doctor: Oh, so you had a study, or they had a, uh, a program that sort of reduced your cost? Patient: Probably a program. Doctor: ‘Cuz we would put the prescription into our pharmacy. We would have them figure out how much it’s gonna cost you, and then if it’s too much, they could start looking for these plans that they cover the cost for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if that’s so, then it would be cheap. Then you would be taking a drug that I don’t think is gonna work with the idea that I need you to be on this drug so that the immune therapy might work which is research, experimental, unsure. Okay? Family Member: Is there any way on the portal – his daughter wants to keep up what’s, what’s going over -- like what we said today. Does she have your power of something? Have some way that she can check on, uh – like MyLGHHealth, I can go in there and see, read everything, and results and that. Doctor: Yeah, I mean, he is active on MyChart. That’s where I wrote you that note.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: The bone biopsy for you would be similar to any kind of biopsy. They have to numb up your skin, and put a needle, and take a piece of whatever they’re trying to take a piece of. For us, the bone biopsy, the yield is much lower, meaning they don’t always get actual tumor cells, because within the bone, it’s just they’re sort of taking a shot at, you know, what they think might be the tumor. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but those trials are, are, uh, the primary hormone in this case it would be drug called, Xtandi, plus another pill. So it’s a pill-based kind of trial in that sense. Patient: Um hum. Um hum. Doctor: Uh, and the, uh, the other trial we have is my, I talked before about this bone marrow transplant trial, which, um, is, you know, more kind of aggressive, uh, and kind of still in its early stages. So I can’t tell ya much about- we’ve treated two patients, and, uh, they both did really well with the bone marrow transplant. One guy has been pretty stable for, you know, going on two years, and one guy’s disease responded, and then it sort of progressed now, and he’s, he’s on chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So probably one guy benefited and one guy has not. Uh, we’re about to do a third guy probably in the next few weeks. So, uh, but I think that trial I would probably want you to have at least been on one of the hormone drugs first. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Because those drugs do improve how long people live and are relatively easy. So I think I would, even though that’s my trial, the bone marrow transplant trial, it’s designed for people like you who are young- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Um, the, uh, I would rather first do something that at least has a track record of success. Does that make sense?

text: Doctor: Sure. What we will- the nice part about this, is you sign up for what you can do. The minute it doesn’t go right, then we just stop. That’s the good part. That’s the really good part. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay. During the- this is different than the Lupron and that right? Isn’t this usually used for gastric? Doctor: It’s all, yeah, but there’s a lot of information for earlier states like now. So it’s also been given in men right before their surgery stages. We know that the cancer cells are dying in the actual prostate. So it’s been given in every possible place, but the FDA approval is when you’re castrate resistant. Yeah. Patient: Okay. That’s what I read. Doctor: I know. Man. What happened here? Did you teach him stuff? Family Member: I didn’t, actually. Doctor: Wow. That’s great. Family Member: He’s a smart guy. Doctor: He is a smart guy. (Laughs) Patient: I used to do research for college professors sometimes in school. Patient: I used to work in the library, and they’d come in, can you give me a bibliography of the? (Laughs) Patient: Yeah.

text: Patient: The only e-mail that I got was a confirmation that they had received my test. Family Member: But that was the only thing, right? Not that that’s a small thing, but that was – there was no other genetic, uh, information. Doctor: Actually, I gave you the wrong information. I’m sorry. So, it’s actually a higher chance that they inherit it because it’s --- I, I forgot this is what’s called – so there’s two kinds of mutations; dominant and recessive. So, recessive means you have to, uh, uh, get, uh, two bad copies to – I want to say it’s a twenty-five percent chance because you have to get two bad copies. But, in this case, if you get one bad copy, you are at risk even though you have one good copy. So, in that case, it sort of takes out your, the mother. So, they, they have a fifty percent chance of getting this gene from you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So, uh, so if they get it, they’re at risk, and if they don’t get it – so, it’s a fifty-fifty as opposed to a recessive where they have a fifty percent chance from you and a fifty percent chance from the mother, and they have to get two copies to have a problem. Patient: Okay. But – Doctor: So, that makes it twenty-five percent. Patient: If they are negative ---- Doctor: If they’re negative, they’re negative. Patient: It’s over. Doctor: It’s over. Patient: Okay.

text: Patient: Two months, two weeks, yeah. Doctor: Was at zero point five. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay, so that’s very good news because it’s a very slight - Patient: Okay. text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I want to make sure on the studies everybody gets pictures of the same time points so that we can see when the cancer changes. Patient: And another question that I have. At one point we talked to acupuncturist and he said he can help through acupuncture with peeing problems. So and I was thinking we’d go on the day when we take the catheter our, but now I’m thinking maybe I should wait. And now if that is okay, see if that may be some additional help. Doctor: I don’t know. I think it’s reasonable to try. You know most acupuncturists will ask you about your current situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - and see how well it would help. You know my worry is you know if you’re spending money on that then how does it help? You know if they are doing it and you get the catheter out is it because of my drug or because they gave you, you know acupuncture and how long you paid them? Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: And so those are all issues that you’ve got to sort out. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: How do you know it’s working? Family Member: I think that we should probably wait until catheter is out.

text: Patient: Right. Yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah, yeah I know all of that. Doctor: So -. Family Member: Does insurance do anything with this? I mean, do they consider you a risk? Are you -- Doctor: I don’t know. Um, you, you, they’re going to need to talk with their doctors. I do know that the test we did, I think, allows, if we, a discounted test, I’ll find out --- for family members, um, to test as well. Um, there is just a test for BRCA, and then there’s a, you know, at this point these tests are, cover about thirty different genes. Um. That’s the only one they found. So, for your family, I think it, it requires a discussion about it, and then they should – you know, they need to make a decision if they want to get tested or not. Um. It’s a risk factor for prostate and breast. So, and ovarian, so both sons and daughters, and then, you know, their sons and daughters if they – I would say if they were positive. I do know that the test we did, I think, allows, if we, a discounted test, I’ll find out --- for family members, um, to test as well. Um, there is just a test for BRCA, and then there’s a, you know, at this point these tests are, cover about thirty different genes. Um. That’s the only one they found. So, for your family, I think it, it requires a discussion about it, and then they should – you know, they need to make a decision if they want to get tested or not. Um. It’s a risk factor for prostate and breast. So, and ovarian, so both sons and daughters, and then, you know, their sons and daughters if they – I would say if they were positive. If they were negative, there’s – you know, your grandkids are – it, it can’t skip over it – so, if your sons or daughter is negative (coughs) Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: Unless their – Family Member: Their husband has it – Doctor: Unless their husband or wife has it. Family Member: Right. Well the one that has, um, the children, is in the military. So, she has access to really good medical care and probably could do this at little cost or, I don’t know. Patient: Well. Who cares about the cost for Christ’s sake? Family Member: Well, no, I mean, but she has good medical care. So. Doctor: Well, again, I could, we could even do the test we just did, um, Family Member: It’s easy for her to get tested for anything. You know what I mean? If she wants to.

Patient: And he’s said he’s had good luck with other patients that have had pain with that Cymbalta.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
